awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Manufacturing USA: Energy Efficient Processing of Thermosetting Polymers and Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project will research a new method for the manufacture of plastics and fiber reinforced composite materials, which are critical elements in structures like aircraft, automobiles and wind turbine blades, where light weight and high strength are required. Current methods for manufacturing these materials are costly and energy intensive, due to the high temperatures and long times required for processing.  Drawing inspiration from how living system develop, this multidisciplinary research project will result in new plastic materials that require only small initial energy input to rapidly trigger the entire manufacturing process and dramatically reduce environmental impact. This new, more efficient method has significant potential to improve U.S. economic competitiveness in the critical area of composites manufacturing. The energy efficient concepts under development also provide an ideal platform to motivate and educate the next generation of students, postdoctoral researchers, entrepreneurs, industry and the general public on the importance of sustainable manufacturing. 
 
A new manufacturing method for thermosetting polymers, coatings and composites will be developed based on an autocatalytic (self-propagating) polymerization reaction occurring in a system undergoing reaction and diffusion of its components. The system uses the exothermic release of energy to provide a positive feedback to the reaction. In turn, this stimulates further exothermic energy release and a self-propagating reaction front that rapidly moves through the material; a process called frontal polymerization.  Once triggered, the reaction progresses with zero energy input.  The self-sustained propagation of a reaction wave through the material gives rise to entirely new ways of rapidly manufacturing high performance polymers and composites, without the use of conventional autoclaves or ovens. The planned research will lead to scientific advances in the organic chemistry of self-propagating reactions, machine learning driven design and synthesis of new monomers for frontal polymerization, multiscale characterization and modeling of front instabilities, and control of frontal polymerization for manufacturing.  The research objectives are designed to improve fundamental understanding of frontal polymerization and to apply this knowledge to the rapid out-of-autoclave production of thermosetting coatings, fiber-reinforced composites and 3D printed architecturally complex, reinforced polymers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This research project developed a new technology for the much faster and more energy efficient processing of plastics and fiber-reinforced composites, which are critical elements in many engineering structures like aircraft, automobiles, and wind turbine blades, where light weight, high strength, and good environmental properties are required. Current manufacturing of these materials using bulk polymerization in large ovens or autoclaves is complex, long, costly, and energy intensive due to the large capital investments and amounts of heat required. This fundamental research project examined a promising curing method known as frontal polymerization (FP) in which the exothermic nature of the reaction leads to a self-sustaining polymerization front that propagates through the manufactured part transforming the liquid monomer or complaint gel into a stiff polymer. Due to the very small initial energy input needed to trigger the entire manufacturing process, this novel out-of-autoclave technique produces high-performance thermosetting polymers and composite much faster and with much less environmental impact than conventional autoclave-based methods. The team also showed the method is applicable to 3D printing processes allowing for the rapid creation of complex free-standing parts.

Intellectual Merit:  Our research activities were divided into four collaborative areas: (1) enabling chemistries and materials, (2) manufacturing test beds and characterization, (3) processing science and modeling. Significant outcomes have been achieved for each area, resulting in at total of 25 archival journal papers, and summarized below.

(1) We explored the reactivity of over 30 different monomers and characterized their performance for frontal polymerization and the associated manufacturing parameters such as the speed of the curing process (front velocity), the pot life of the system (gel time), and the degree of cure.  We also examined how additives can be incorporated in the resin to affect FP and to improve the adhesion of the frontally polymerized resin to the reinforcing fibers.

(2) We investigated multiple strategies to initiate and optimize the FP-based manufacturing process, such as the use of multiple polymerization front for the manufacturing of large parts, through-thickness FP for the fast and efficient curing of composite panels with high fiber volume fractions and the UV-light-based initiation of the front. We also identified the conditions in which the cure front is self-regulating during the FP-based 3-D printing of complex geometries.

(3) The modeling effort has relied primarily on the reaction-diffusion description of the initiation and propagation of the polymerization front, allowing us to capture the effect of heat losses to the surrounding and the impact of the cure kinetic parameters on the manufacturing process. The model was combined with an optimization scheme to achieve high-quality composite parts while further reducing the energy input needed to trigger the FP process. We also analyzed experimentally and computationally the conditions in which the FP- and buoyancy-driven convection of the liquid monomer ahead of the front can lead to thermo-chemical instabilities of the front.

Broader Impacts:  Traditional manufacturing approaches for high-performance fiber-reinforced polymer composite (FRPC) requires curing at high temperatures in large ovens that scale in size with the component. This traditional curing approach is slow, requires a large amount of energy, and involves significant capital investment.  Despite growing importance in many sectors, costs are still too high for most consumer products, and fabrication is limited to high value, small batches. Innovation is crucial to U.S. manufacturing competitiveness and could open new products and markets for composites that utilize their unique properties including lower weight, corrosion resistance, and (potentially) reduction in complexity and part count. Our frontal polymerization manufacturing platform technology allows for near net-zero energy fabrication of large-scale components.  Energy efficient manufacturing of composites has potential to reduce the carbon footprint of the composites industry and reduce the consumer cost of products made of composites.  Research from this grant has led to new IP and the creation of a small company focused on commercialization of frontal curing resins and their applications.

   Education impacts center on training of interdisciplinary graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.  The research program resulted in the training of five postdoctoral researchers, three of which now have faculty positions.  Six graduate students successfully completed their PhD dissertations, four of which are employed in the US aerospace/composites industry or national labs. A total of nine undergraduate students conducted research mentored by the graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and PIs working on this project, gaining hands on laboratory experience and presentation skills.  Outreach and education of the general public centered on the creation of exhibit on Sustainable Plastics: Reduce, Repurpose, and Regenerate, at the Beckman Open House Event on March 31-April 1 2023. The UIUC PIs, graduate students, and postdocs created designed a series of interactive demonstrations on frontal polymerization, 3D printing and polymer upcycling. Over 750 K-12 students from schools across the state of Illinois as well as local community members attended our demonstrations and learned about sustainable manufacturing of thermoset polymer


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Nancy R Sottos

Images (1 of )
  • High volume fraction (65%) woven carbon fiber / pDCPD composite manufactured by through thickness curing in less than 2 min.
    Nil Parikh
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Composite Microstructure
  • Photo taken during Sustainable Polymers Exhibit at the Beckman Open House 2023. Over 750 K-12 students attended this outreach event.
    Jeff Moore
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Frontal Polymerization in Action
  • IR image during Direct Ink Writing show reacting front during freeform printing.
    Jia En Aw
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    3D Printing with Frontal Polymerization
  • Carbon fiber / pDCPD composite airfoil shape fabricated via frontal polymerization.
    Nil Parikh
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Complex composite fabricated by frontal curing
  • Motivated by the use of frontal polymerization for the manufacturing of thin layers with thickness down to ∼100 μm, we numerically and experimentally investigate the interplay between the exothermic polymerization and the heat losses to the substrate.
    Yuan Gao
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Frontal Polymerization of Thin Layers on a Thermally Insulating Substrate
  • Design for FP-based manufacturing requires characterization and prediction of material evolution and residual deformation throughout the process. Based on the experimental output, a coupled thermo−chemo−mechanical model has been developed to capture the measured residual strains.
    Zhuoting Chen, Behrad Koohbor
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Residual Strain Development in Rapid Frontally Curing Polymers
